awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Development of Atomically Thin Tunnel Barriers for High-Performance Tunnel Junctions
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical:
Tunnel junctions are an enabling technology for future electronics. They are formed by inserting a thin insulating layer, known as a tunnel barrier, between metal or semiconductor electrodes. Devices based on tunnel junctions have the advantages of enhanced quantum coherent transport, fast speed, small size and energy efficiency. Tunnel junctions are used, for example, in sensors, flash memory and in quantum or neural computers. The performance of a tunnel junction depends critically on the quality and thickness of the tunnel barrier. Charge transport through a barrier, known as quantum tunneling, increases exponentially with decreasing layer thickness and defect concentration. Despite decades of effort, current tunnel junction technology is limited to barriers that are at least one nanometer thick and have a high defect density. Creating atomically thin (one tenth of a nanometer), defect-free tunnel barriers will enable the next-generation of tunnel junction devices. This project will advance tunnel junction technology by creating atomically thin, high-quality tunnel barriers using atomic layer deposition. Two important types of tunnel junctions will be studied. Superconducting Josephson junctions serve as quantum bits (qubits) for quantum computers. Magnetic tunnel junctions are at the heart of nonvolatile, fast magnetic random access memory and neuromorphic computers. The scientific knowledge developed through this project will broadly impact the development of future microelectronics. Atomic scale control of materials and interfaces applies to sensing, catalysis, and energy production. The project emphasizes forefront education and the cutting-edge research. This will attract students, especially those from underrepresented groups, to pursue careers in STEM.

Technical:
This project focuses on the development of atomically thin tunnel barriers by atomic layer deposition (ALD) for use in tunnel junction devices. The goal is to understand and control the physical and chemical properties of materials used in tunnel junctions at atomic scales for high performance devices in order to achieve defect-free, atomically thin tunnel barriers. Despite exciting preliminary results on Josephson junctions and magnetic tunnel junctions with 0.1-1.0 nm thick Al2O3 tunnel barriers, many fundamental questions remain in synthesis and physical properties of these tunnel junctions. Two topics are proposed to answer these questions. Topic 1 will focus on growth of Josephson junctions and magnetic tunnel junctions using a custom-designed system for in situ ultra-high-vacuum atomic layer deposition-physical vapor deposition (ALD-PVD) for tunnel junction deposition. This system is integrated with a characterization system with scanning probe microscopy and tip-enhanced Raman spectroscopy (SPM-TERS) capabilities. The SPM-TERS system will be used to understand the growth mechanism of the ALD tunnel barriers and the metal-insulator (M/I) interface and the role of growth parameters, such as ALD growth temperature, source pulse durations and sequence will be investigated. Experimental work will be guided by simulation. Topic 2 will carry out in situ study of the tunnel barriers and the electrode/tunnel barrier interface using UHV SPM-TERS and multi-scale characterization at device and circuit levels to understand the microscopic properties of insulating barrier and electrode/tunnel barrier interface, especially the effect of defects, on the performance of superconducting qubits, Josephson junctions, and magnetic tunnel junctions. The goal is to demonstrate an innovative technological approach towards next-generation high-performance electronics based on tunnel junctions with ALD tunnel barriers.

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this project is to obtain atomically thin tunnel barriers (TBs) in metal/insulator/metal tunnel junctions (TJs) that can have high quantum coherent transport, fast speed, small size and high energy-efficiency demanded as the fundamental building blocks for advanced computing. The goal is to understand and control the physical and chemical properties of materials used in tunnel junctions at atomic scales for high performance devices in order to achieve defect-free, atomically thin tunnel barriers. Two important types of tunnel junctions will be studied. Superconducting Josephson junctions serve as quantum bits (qubits) for quantum computers. Magnetic tunnel junctions are at the heart of nonvolatile, fast magnetic random access memory and neuromorphic computers. The primary focus of the project is to answer several fundamental questions in research and development of metal-insulator-metal tunnel junctions with TBs made using atomic layer deposition (ALD). These questions include: 1) What is the physics governing the nucleation of the tunnel barriers on functional metal electrodes in atomic ALD process?  2) What are the key parameters in controlling the defects in the TB and at the interfaces between the TB and electrodes? 3) What are the effects of TB quality on the properties of TJ-based devices?

The project has achieved an important understanding of the growth mechanism of ultrathin insulating tunnel barriers for TJs with a defect-free metal/insulator interface (Topic 1) and the fabrication and characterization of TJs including Josephson junctions and magnetic tunnel junctions (Topic 2).  In Topic 1, the research was focused on understand the growth mechanism of ultrathin (0.1 nm-few nm) dielectric films using in vacuo atomic layer deposition (ALD) of Al2O3, MgO, MaAl2O4 on functional metal electrodes including superconducting Al, Nb and ferromagnetic Fe. In addition, the effect of inserting MgO atomic layers into ALD Al2O3 atomic layer stacks on the microstructure and electronic structure has been investigated. Remarkably, this study has demonstrated not only that leak-free, defect-free insulating tunnel barriers as thin as 0.1 nm can be achieved on metal electrodes over a large scale but also the arbitrary stakes of different  atomic layers for tunable electronic structures (such bandgaps).   

In Topic 2, the research was focused on in situ characterization of electronic structure and defects of ultrathin dielectric films (made in Topic 1) using ultrahigh vacuum scanning tunneling spectroscopy (UHV-STS) and ex situ characterization of devices. Josephson junctions with ALD-Al2O3 tunnel barriers as thin as 0.2 nm and magnetic tunnel junctions based on ALD-MgO tunnel barrier of only 0.5 nm in thickness on Fe electrodes were obtained successfully for the first time. The correlation between in situ materials characterization and ex situ device characterization is the key to the success of this project.

The key outcomes of this project include 10 invention disclosures, three US patents issued, >70 publications generated including 5 invited book chapters and 5 invited reviews. In addition, >40 presentations (~25 invited/plenary) were given by the PI and her group at regional, national and international workshops and conferences.

This project has provided training at different levels of post-graduate, graduate and undergraduate researchers in a team setting, which provides a highly interactive and dynamic training environment. This has multiple benefits to trainees including: 1) team-work experience and leadership development; 2) broad knowledge and research skills; and 3) interdisciplinary research approaches. Over the project period, the PI’s group has hosted a large number of researchers at different levels including 2 postdocs, 15 PhD students (7 finished during the project period and 8 current), 4 undergraduates and 3 high schoolers on research topics of thin films and devices, graphene fabrication and characterization, and functional ceramic dielectrics, respectively. 7 PhD dissertations were completed (one received honor) and they are employed both in US and across the world as university faculty, research staff in research institutions and US industry including Intel, Honeywell, etc. All undergraduate researchers have entered/or plan to enter PhD programs and all high school researchers are in colleges for STEM studies.    

This project’s outcome also includes a series education/outreach activities carried out by PI and her group, especially through a collaboration of KU National History Museum Education in development of online and hands-on activities for K-12 students/teachers and public. For example, the Science Shorts—a set of four mini animated videos about nanoscience, solar energy and electricity has now had more than 1,200,000 views at the Quarked! Adventures in the Subatomic Universe website (www.quarked.org), which continues to have visitors from more than 100 countries and had more than 150,000 unique visits each year. The PI has been an important part of the hands-on outreach program led by the KU Natural History Museum before COVID pandemic and recently after the opening of in-person activities, which has >1000 participants during the project period including ~500 school program participants.
